awd_abstract_narration: 1321470 (Davis). Smart Manufacturing (SM) is integrating network-based data and information that comprises the real-time understanding, reasoning, planning and management of all aspects of a manufacturing and supply chain enterprise. SM is facilitated through use of advanced sensor-based data analytics, modeling and simulation in real-time. SM is about game-changing potential to energize innovation, address productivity, achieve new and structurally different performance goals, and drive the competitive advantage of investments in plant assets. Unfortunately, a cost effective infrastructure to integrate real-time manufacturing intelligence and active management across the control systems of an entire production operation does not exist today. This is the ultimate aim of the Smart Manufacturing Leadership Coalition (SMLC). SMLC has been formed around a set of goals that no one company can accomplish alone. SMLC enables stakeholders in the smart manufacturing industry to form collaborative R & D, implementation and advocacy teams for development of the approaches, standards, platforms and shared infrastructure that facilitate the broad utilization of manufacturing intelligence. The SMLC is a non-profit organization committed to overcome barriers to the development and deployment of SM Systems through development of a shared infrastructure called the Smart Manufacturing Platform (SM Platform). SMLC activities are built around joint industry and university-driven development, application and scaling of a shared infrastructure that will achieve transformational economic-wide impact, manufacturing innovation and global competitiveness. SMLC supports the manufacturing industry through pursuing a comprehensive technology that no one company can undertake. Without a modern industrial infrastructure, adoption of SM systems is not economically viable. Process control and automation systems implemented in a piecemeal fashion will continue to limit innovation and capability. SMLC will build the business, interoperability and technology models, demonstrations, infrastructure, and project teams across multiple industry segments. Through the SM Platform, SMLC will help companies address manufacturing-related challenges across the automotive, food, military, materials, chemical, oil and gas, refining, pharmaceutical, information technology, process control and automation industries. SMLC also supports collaborative research, development and commercialization. Education and workforce training resources for smart manufacturing will be developed for universities, technology schools, and small and medium manufacturers.

The Smart Manufacturing Leadership Coalition (SMLC) is an industry, academic, government, national laboratory and agency coalition that that has grown to 60 members during the three years of this NSF funding. The SMLC originally formed around the premises that (1) manufacturing operations are critical to U.S. competitiveness, (2) there is significant untapped opportunity for productivity (workforce, energy, material and economic) gains at the enterprise and supply chain through the application of data and next generation information technology, and (3) shared platform infrastructure that no one company can provide is key to the digitalization of the manufacturing operation.  

The SMLC originated the vocabulary of Smart Manufacturing. Over the past three years the SMLC has undertaken significant effort to (1) develop an industry defined consensus on the business, market and technology drivers for Smart Manufacturing, (2) use diverse industry test beds to define the Smart Manufacturing Platform (SM Platform and Marketplace) as the industry-defined shared infrastructure, (3) work with users and providers on new business models and (4) communicate and leverage these findings in further refined specification.  A review of the activities in the annual reports reveal several dedicated workshops on subjects that include: what is a test bed, smart grid, what is Smart Manufacturing, visualization, demonstrations of the Smart Manufacturing Platform, advanced sensor, control, platforms and modeling (ASCPM) and IoT. There were numerous webinars by varied stakeholders across its membership including EPRI, General Mills, Praxair, GE, Aloca, Savigent , OSIsoft, MESA, MT Connect, Center for Innovation and Visualization at Purdue Calumet, Education and Workforce Development. SMLC members participated in more than 35 invited workshops and conferences.

During this three-year time period, SMLC members participated on Advanced Manufacturing Partnership (AMP2.0) workgroups, various agency workshops to set priority manufacturing directions and priorities for the National Network of Manufacturing Innovation Institutes (NNMIs). SMLC involvement and fingerprints can be observed in the recommendations to form an Innovation Institute on Smart Manufacturing; the importance of materials manufacture; the importance of and distinctions with the Digital Manufacturing Design Innovation Institute (DMDII); and recommendation to form an entity to recommend priority manufacturing technology areas across agencies. DOE last year released a Funding Opportunity Announcement (FOA) for a Clean Energy Institute on Smart Manufacturing; NSF awarded the cross agency manufacturing leadership group to ‘mForesight’ in Michigan.

In efforts to ensure the open platform technology development is industry-driven, the SMLC has conducted numerous activities and engaged cross-sector industries and stakeholders to evaluate SMLC’s progress and directions. The technology development has resulted in building industry-driven value propositions and requirements that no one entity can achieve alone. The SMLC has demonstrated success in developing a strong, public-private collaboration across industry, academic, association, and government stakeholders. SMLC has continued to develop and refine a grounded, actionable vision and program agenda for collaborative Smart Manufacturing.

Through numerous webinars, publications, reports, presentations and workshops, the SMLC has successfully connected education, workforce and the research communities to build a sustainable pipeline that aligns with the manufacturing industry’s needs.

These results would not have been possible without the SMLC significantly honing its industry driven definition of Smart Manufacturing and applying it to multiple test bed projects:
